steps.label: What is a CV for?
desc: CVs and résumés are essential documents for the initial stage of applying for a job. They are both accounts of someone’s education, qualifications, skills and work experience.

In the US, a résumé is a short summary of a person’s experience and qualifications, while a CV is more often used for academic positions and is a longer, more comprehensive document. In the UK, a CV is similar to an American résumé and is a summary of an applicant’s education and work experience that is adapted to the job being applied for. For all types of CV and résumé, the information given must be up to date and accurate.
It is advisable to check with a teacher or tutor if there are any special conventions you should use.
Also look at the covering/cover letter.

steps.label: How is it structured?
desc: Below is the framework that was used to create this CV.

A CV should include all the relevant experience, skills and qualifications for the job being applied for as well as details of your education starting from your final year at school. You can draw out further relevant experience and highlight your skills in the covering letter that accompanies the CV.

steps.label: Personal information
desc: The labels, 'Name', Address', etc. can be omitted. There is no need to mention your age, gender, nationality, race, religion or marital status. Don't send a photo unless you are asked to.

steps.label: Profile
desc: You do not have to include this, but it gives an employer an idea of who you are.

steps.label: Education and qualifications
desc: Put the most recent first and do not include information about primary school. Add prizes and awards. Try to give British equivalents of your qualifications.

steps.label: Work experience
desc: This is also shown in reverse order, beginning with the most recent. As this is the CV of a recent graduate, it includes holiday and part-time work.

steps.label: Skills
desc: These are the practical abilities of the applicant. The section also includes any formal qualifications relating to these skills.

steps.label: Interests
desc: This is a short section. It includes things like sport, creative activities and community activities, but not vague subjects such as 'reading' or 'travel'.

checkList.text: Collect together all the information you need to include in your CV.
Select information that is relevant to the job you are applying for.
Make sure all the information is accurate.
Use action verbs and adjectives to present yourself positively.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Action verbs

Use action verbs to describe your achievements and make them look more dynamic.

Examples: achieved, administered, advised, analysed, arranged, compiled, conducted, coordinated, created, designed, developed, devised, distributed, evaluated, examined, executed, implemented, increased, instructed, introduced, liaised, managed, mentored, monitored, negotiated, organized, oversaw, prepared, recommended, reduced, represented, researched, solved, supervised, trained

Positive Adjectives

Use positive adjectives to describe yourself.

Examples: active, adaptable, committed, competent, dynamic, effective, efficient, enthusiastic, experienced, flexible, (highly) motivated, organized, professional, proficient, qualified, successful
